awd_titl_txt: Spatially Defined Radical-Containing Polymers for Enhanced Charge Transfer
awd_abstract_narration:
With the support of the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program in the Division of Chemistry, Drs. Emily Pentzer and Jodie Lutkenhaus from Texas A&M University will advance the fundamental knowledge of how the placement of groups that can transfer electrons (dubbed “redox-active groups”) on polymers and particles impacts their ability to store and produce electrical energy. This will be accomplished by preparing polymers with controlled spacing between redox-active groups, then determining how the structure of these polymers impact their ability to move electrical charges. The advanced knowledge produced through this work may lead to ground breaking advances for energy, electronic, and medical applications, such as enabling organic polymers to replace the metal components of batteries. In addition to the scientific research, undergraduate students, graduate students, and a postdoctoral researcher will be trained to address complex problems and be productive members of a collaborative STEM workforce; educational videos and hands-on demonstrations will be produced and shared; and high school women will be mentored through the US National Academy of Engineering EngineerGirl website. 

Three different classes materials will be synthesized and used to identify the relationship between structure and electrochemical properties. One organic redox-active group will be used for these studies (2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine-1-oxyl (TEMPO)), and the knowledge gained should be applicable to other redox-active units. In the first class of materials, the organization of the TEMPO units around a polymer backbone will be varied; in this class, the number of atoms between the TEMPO units will remain the same but their spatial orientation around will be different. In the second class of materials, the spacing between TEMPO units on a polymer backbone will be varied; in this class, the number of atoms between the TEMPO units will be changed. The third class of materials that will be prepared are solid spherical particles that are decorated with either TEMPO groups or short polymer chains that contain TEMPO groups; these decorated particles will be added to the TEMPO-containing polymers. The different structures of the three classes are expected to change how the TEMPO units interact with each other in a solid film, and thus how electrical energy can be stored. The physical and electrochemical properties of the materials will be thoroughly characterized and the work will likely produce knowledge on how material structure correlates to transfer of electrons and ions in polymer-based materials.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit.

Organic batteries have emerged as promising alternatives to Li-ion batteries because the organic platform can potentially address the pressing needs of safety and use of domestic feedstocks. Organic batteries offer a safer platform based on redox-active polymers comprised of earth-abundant and readily available elements carbon, hydrogen, nitrogen, oxygen, and sulfur. For this emerging technology to realize broader adoption, it is critically important to understand the mechanism by which energy is stored in organic active materials. This project bridged this knowledge gap through the exploration of polymers and polymer-functionalized nanoparticles with redox-active groups of controlled spatial definition. Specifically, by controlling the distance between the redox-active groups, the mechanism of energy storage was further resolved. The redox group of particular interest contained a nitroxide radical.

 

The first area of this project explored the effect of placing the redox-active group at certain carbon-spacings along the hydrocarbon polymer backbone. A controlled polymerization technique called ADMET (acyclic diene metathesis) was used to produce polymers with the desired active group spacings. By changing the spacing, the glass transition (or the temperature at which the polymer softens) changed as well. It was determined that an intermediate carbon spacing led to a desirable combination of reduction-oxidation diffusion and kinetics, as a result of that polymer having the lowest glass transition temperature. The primary impact of this work was the discovery of a new physical relationship between the reduction-oxidation diffusion and kinetics and the glass transition temperature. This discovery indicates that polymers with low glass transition temperatures are likely to perform better as active materials in organic batteries.

 

In the second area of this project, the effect of tacticity of the redox-active polymer was exploited. Tacticity describes whether the redox-active groups lie on the same side of the polymer chain or not, with “isotactic” indicating groups on the same side, “syndiotactic” being groups on alternating sides, and “atactic” having groups with no preference for one side or the other.  The general approach involved the anionic polymerization of a nitroxide radical-bearing monomer with different catalysts, ligands, and reaction conditions. The atactic polymer showed higher redox-activity, as well as a lower mass change during oxidation; this could be a result of the better electrolyte accessibility in the atactic polymer. The impact of this work is that it shows that redox-activity is promoted when the groups have a random orientation along the backbone.

 

In the third area of this project, the modification of charge transport pathways of redox active polymers solutions was explored. Specifically, particles with nitroxide radical-containing, redox-active polymer grafts or brushes were synthesized using controlled radical polymerization. The grafted particles were added to solutions of the same type redox-active polymer. Increases in the reduction-oxidation diffusion and kinetics were observed upon adding the grafted particles. It was discovered that the polymer grafts could act as “bridges” to more effectively transport charge in the solution. The impact of this work is that this knowledge can impact the design of electrolytes for redox-flow batteries, in which reduction-oxidation activity can be promoted by simply adding grafted particles.

 

Broader Impacts.

Our findings contribute to the understanding of structure-property-performance relationships of non-conjugated redox active soft matter for applications in organic batteries. These results can impact other application of redox active polymers in applications such as catalysis, as well as other applications such as ion exchange membranes, organic magnetic materials, and medical imaging, beyond our inspiration to understand electrochemical energy storage.

Through this project, multiple graduate students (including a US veteran) and a postdoc have been supported in their thesis research, and they developed skills critical to thriving in the US STEM workforce in the areas of chemistry, chemical engineering, and electrochemistry. The results were disseminated in peer-reviewed publications, national conferences, and seminars.

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 04/14/2025
Modified by: Emily B Pentzer
